column1:
commodity /ˈkɒmədɪtjuː/
Examples: Crude oil is one of the most traded commodities globally. The local market provides various agricultural products as commodities.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A raw material or primary product held by a trader for the purpose of resale, often in bulk and subject to price fluctuations
column2: any valuable thing that can be bought or sold.

column1:
snub [ˈsnʌb]
Examples: 'I felt snubbed when I waited for hours and nobody showed up'; 'He thought his ex-girlfriend had forgotten about him, but it was just a simple case of being misunderstood.',"Part of Speech: verb, noun
Definition: 'Snub' as a verb means to ignore or treat with contempt
column2: 'snub' as a noun refers to an act of ignoring someone.

column1:
impetuous /ˌɪmpəˈtjuː.ʃli/
Examples: The impetuous teenager stormed out of the room in anger, not realizing he had left his homework behind. /She spoke her mind with such an impetuous tone that it surprised everyone at dinner.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: Having or showing passionate intensity

succumbed /ˌsʌkˈvʌmbd/
Examples: After years of struggling with addiction, she finally succumbed without the last crutch. The oppressive regime's fear tactics led many citizens to surrender their rights and hope for change.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: Admitted defeat or death, often as a result of pressure or temptation
column2: Yielded to an unpleasant personality trait.

column1:
secularized /ˈsekjʊləreɪt/
Examples: '90s politics was heavily influenced by religious ideologies before they were largely secularized in recent years.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: to remove religion from a particular sphere, such as education or governance
column2: secularize (v.) - to subject to the principles of secularism.

column1:
emanates [ɛˌmænˈeɪtiz]
Examples: The warmth emanated throughout the room as if it were alive; The music emanating softly in her mind was soothing and comforting.,"Part of Speech: verb

column2: exudes, spreads outwards or flows from a source.

column1:
flounder /ˈflundər/
Examples: 'I really don't know what I want for dinner,' John mumbled as he floundered through the grocery store options. 'Her ideas often seem shallow and unconvincing, like they are merely flouncing around without a solid foundation.',"Part of Speech: verb and noun
Definition: a verb meaning to move or speak in a confused, hesitant way
column2: an adjective referring to something that lacks substance or appeal.

column1:
eminently [ɪˈmɪn.ənt]
Examples: 'Emily was eminently talented at painting'; 'The event went eminently well without any issues'.,"Part of Speech: adverb

column2: to a high degree or extent, especially in a positive sense.

column1:
embroiled /ɪmˈbrɔɪld/
Examples: She found her life embroiled when she took the job offer abroad. The small town was embroiled in political turmoil due to an election scandal.,"Part of Speech: adjective

column2: involved in a difficult or complicated situation, typically one from which it is hard to extricate oneself.

column1:
transfixed /ˌtrænfˈlɪst/
Examples: She was transfixed by the mesmerizing performance and did not move for hours afterwards.; The audience remained transfixed as they watched the terrifying magic act unfold before them.,"Part of Speech: adjective

visceral /ˈvɪzərəl/
Examples: 'It was a visceral reaction he had, seeing blood for the first time,' she said. 'He felt sick and uncomfortable.' Another example: 'Her anger towards him became more visceral as their argument escalated.',"Part of Speech: adjective

column2: pertaining to the internal organs of the body.

column1:
niche /ˈniːʃ/
Examples: The company found success by carving out its niche in organic pet foods. She decided to pursue a career as an environmental consultant, finding her unique professional niche.,"Part of Speech: noun, verb
Definition: A specialized segment of the market for a specific product or service
column2: to identify and satisfy particular customer needs.

column1:
culminating /ˌkʌl.mɪnˈeɪ.t̬iŋ/,
Examples: 'The project's work had been building up for years before finally reaching its culminating stage.' 'His speech was truly inspiring and set a new standard in political discourse, marking it as his most culminating contribution to date.',"Part of Speech: verb, adjective

stifled /stɪˈfleɪt/
Examples: She stifled a sob when she saw him leave. The room was stuffy and made her feel as if she were being stifled.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: to suppress or hold back the voice, breathing
column2: to make (a sound) inaudible by restraint of speech.

column1:
chastened /ˈtʃeɪstənd/
Examples: She was chastened by her son for misbehaving at dinner. He learned a valuable lesson that left him feeling much more chastened about his actions.,"Part of Speech: adjective and past participle of the verb 'chasten'
Definition: Having been corrected or disciplined in some way

provincials /prəˌvɪnsəlz/
Examples: The southern provincials were proud of their local craftsmen.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: Natives of a province or region
column2: people not from the metropolitan area.

column1: Synonyms: local residents, countryside folk, provincial inhabitants

rigorous ˈrɪɡərəs;
Examples: 'I need to follow a rigorous study plan if I want to ace the exam.' 'The company has very stringent quality control measures in place.',"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: imposing strict requirements or standards, thorough and precise.

column7: scrupharmonious with one of these words is likely not found due to lack of context and direct antonym, but based on the meaning 'rigorous' implies strictness or difficulty.

column1:
rekindled rek-i-ndid
Examples: After years of silence, their friendship was rekindled when they met unexpectedly at the coffee shop. The old school spirit within her felt fully rekindled as soon as she stepped onto campus.,"Part of Speech: verb, adjective
Definition: To revive a feeling or interest
column2: to restore vigor in an existing relationship.

column1:
maneuvers /ˌmeɪnjʊərˈvoʊz/
Examples: 'The military was executing complex maneuvers during the drill'; 'During negotiations, they used various diplomatic maneuvers.',"Part of Speech: noun, verb
Definition: planned actions or strategies designed to achieve a specific goal

complacency /ˌkɒmpəˈsensi/
Examples: He displayed a dangerous complacency that led to his downfall. Her lack of ambition was born from too much workplace complacency.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: a feeling of smug or satisfied happiness with oneself, one'softs situation, etc., often without awareness of an underlying defect.

tactile ˈtæk.tɪ.əl;
Examples: The artist’s tactile paintings invite viewers to appreciate not just the visual aspects but also the textures; The baby'sense her mother's gentle touch is both comforting and stimulating, offering a pure example of tactile affection.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: capable of being perceived or felt as touch, especially: producing a pleasing texture that can be appreciated by the sense of touch.

oar ˈoʊ.ər;ˈweər;ˈeɪɔːr
Examples: 'They sat at the bottom of the lake as they gripped their oars and paddled furiously.';,"Part of Speech: noun, verb
Definition: 'A device used for rowing a boat through water by means of oars'
column2: 'To propel oneself in water using an oar'.

column1:
propel ˈprɒpəl; /ˈprɑː-/ or "\nPropel: verb (used with object)"; an action that makes something go faster, especially by using force
Examples: 'The rocket engines propel the spacecraft through outer space.' 'He used his strong arms to help me propel my bike uphill.'; an action that makes something go faster, especially by using force,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: an act of driving forward or pushing onward.

bohemian /ˈbɒ.hɪ.ni/ (US), /ˈboʊ.ˌhiː.ni/ (UK)
Examples: 's 'The Diving Bell and the Butterfly,' which chronicles his life as locked inside his body after suffering brain damage from an accident. The book explores themes often found in bohemian literature, such as non-conformity, spiritual questing, and personal liberation.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: a person who lives an unconventional lifestyle, often in a Bohemian style
column2: someone espousing the values of freedom and disregard for conventional society.

column1:
bleaker /ˈbliː.kər/
Examples: The economic report painted a bleaker picture of the future than expected.; Despite all her efforts to stay positive, his constant negativity was making everything seem rather bleak.,"Part of Speech: adjective

column2: darker or more depressed in tone than something else.

column1:
attestation əˈtistɪʃn̩
Examples: 's lawyer presented his client's testamentation as strong proof that he was telling the truth about not being involved with her husband.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: The act of attesting or the evidence in support of a fact, statement, etc.
column2: A formal declaration made to prove something.

column1:
obscure /ˌɒbsəˈkjʊər/
Examples: 'It was an obscure reference, lost on most people.'; The scientist presented her findings with such clarity and precision; However, the true meaning of life remains elusive to me: 'I have always felt it's beyond my understanding.',"Part of Speech: adjective, verb

Definition: make (something) difficult to understand or unclearly expressed: 'The writer's thoughts were so obscure that readers found it hard to interpret them.' Adverb derived from this adjective means done in a way that is not clear or easy to understand.
Synonyms: unclear, vague, ambiguous, imprecise, obscurely expressed

frugally /ˈfruːɡəli/
Examples: She frugally managed her household budget, ensuring she could save for a vacation. He approached the market with his meal plan in hand to avoid unnecessary expenses and shop frugally.,"Part of Speech: 'verb'
Definition: spend money carefully or avoid waste

geodesic /ˌdʒiːoʊˈdiːsɪk/
Examples: The engineer calculated the most efficient route for transportation using principles of geometric design and materials science. The artist's sculpture exemplified minimalist beauty through its seemingly simple yet intricate form, which followed geodesic paths.,"Part of Speech: adjective, noun
Definition: pertaining to or forming a geodesic
column2: shortest path between two points on the surface of a curved space.

column1:
assailed /æˈseɪld/
Examples: The protesters were assailed by tear gas as soon as they started their march. The ancient temple stood steadfast despite centuries of being assailed by natural elements and human conflict.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To attack someone or something violently
column2: to confront in a forceful manner, often causing distress.

column1:
diversions dəˈvɜːrsɪoʊz;-ˌdi-VUR-see-oh-zuhs
Examples: 'I needed some diversions during my boring lecture,' she said. He decided not to dwell on his past mistakes and made light of them as diverting tales;,"Part of Speech: noun, verb
Definition: Noun: activities that distract the mind or attention from something serious or demanding.
column2: Verb: to amuse oneself by engaging in a less important activity.

column1:
menial /ˈmɛnɪəl/
Examples: The menial work in the office included filing and making coffee. She felt that her job was often seen as just another piece of menial labor at home.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: relating to or involving routine tasks

deficiencies ˈdɛfɪˌsensɪz
Examples: 'The educational institution had several deficiencies that needed to be addressed.' 'He acknowledged her honesty but pointed out some personal deficiencies he wanted to work on.',,"Part of Speech: noun plural
Definition: A short definition of 'deficiencies': Are aspects in which something falls below standard or required levels
column2: A longer, more detailed explanation: Significant areas where a person, organization, or process lacks the necessary quality and does not meet an expected level.

column1:
guise /ɡuːˈaɪs/
Examples: He spoke in the guise of an old friend to gain access to her house.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: The external form or appearance of something

menial /ˈmɛnɪəl/
Examples: The menial work in the office included filing and making coffee. She felt that her job was often seen as just another piece of menial labor at home.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: relating to or involving routine tasks

assailed /æˈseɪld/
Examples: The protesters were assailed by tear gas as soon as they started their march. The ancient temple stood steadfast despite centuries of being assailed by natural elements and human conflict.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To attack someone or something violently
column2: to confront in a forceful manner, often causing distress.

column1:
deviating ˈdiːˌvaɪ.tᵈ;
Examples: 'I was planning to go straight home after work but decided to deviate and visit my friend.' 'The course may have several forks along the way; choose which one you wish to take based on your intentions,',"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: to turn aside from a path, route, or set of actions.
Synonyms: diverge from, stray away from, swerve off of

geodesic /ˌdʒiːoʊˈdiːsɪk/
Examples: The engineer calculated the most efficient route for transportation using principles of geometric design and materials science. The artist's sculpture exemplified minimalist beauty through its seemingly simple yet intricate form, which followed geodesic paths.,"Part of Speech: adjective, noun
Definition: pertaining to or forming a geodesic
column2: shortest path between two points on the surface of a curved space.

frugally /ˈfruːɡəli/
Examples: She frugally managed her household budget, ensuring she could save for a vacation. He approached the market with his meal plan in hand to avoid unnecessary expenses and shop frugally.,"Part of Speech: 'verb'
Definition: spend money carefully or avoid waste

Examples: 's lawyer presented his client's testamentation as strong proof that he was telling the truth about not being involved with her husband.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: The act of attesting or the evidence in support of a fact, statement, etc.
column2: A formal declaration made to prove something.

column2: darker or more depressed in tone than something else.

Examples: 'The rocket engines propel the spacecraft through outer space.' 'He used his strong arms to help me propel my bike uphill.'; an action that makes something go faster, especially by using force,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: an act of driving forward or pushing onward.

Examples: 'They sat at the bottom of the lake as they gripped their oars and paddled furiously.';,"Part of Speech: noun, verb
Definition: 'A device used for rowing a boat through water by means of oars'
column2: 'To propel oneself in water using an oar'.

Examples: The artist’s tactile paintings invite viewers to appreciate not just the visual aspects but also the textures; The baby'sense her mother's gentle touch is both comforting and stimulating, offering a pure example of tactile affection.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: capable of being perceived or felt as touch, especially: producing a pleasing texture that can be appreciated by the sense of touch.

rekindled rek-i-ndid
Examples: After years of silence, their friendship was rekindled when they met unexpectedly at the coffee shop. The old school spirit within her felt fully rekindled as soon as she stepped onto campus.,"Part of Speech: verb, adjective
Definition: To revive a feeling or interest
column2: to restore vigor in an existing relationship.

provincials /prəˌvɪnsəlz/
Examples: The southern provincials were proud of their local craftsmen.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: Natives of a province or region
column2: people not from the metropolitan area.

column1: Synonyms: local residents, countryside folk, provincial inhabitants

Examples: She stifled a sob when she saw him leave. The room was stuffy and made her feel as if she were being stifled.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: to suppress or hold back the voice, breathing
column2: to make (a sound) inaudible by restraint of speech.

column1:
niche /ˈniːʃ/
Examples: The company found success by carving out its niche in organic pet foods. She decided to pursue a career as an environmental consultant, finding her unique professional niche.,"Part of Speech: noun, verb
Definition: A specialized segment of the market for a specific product or service
column2: to identify and satisfy particular customer needs.

column1:
flounder /ˈflundər/
Examples: 'I really don't know what I want for dinner,' John mumbled as he floundered through the grocery store options. 'Her ideas often seem shallow and unconvincing, like they are merely flouncing around without a solid foundation.',"Part of Speech: verb and noun
Definition: a verb meaning to move or speak in a confused, hesitant way
column2: an adjective referring to something that lacks substance or appeal.

column1:
secularized /ˈsekjʊləreɪt/
Examples: '90s politics was heavily influenced by religious ideologies before they were largely secularized in recent years.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: to remove religion from a particular sphere, such as education or governance
column2: secularize (v.) - to subject to the principles of secularism.

column1:
snub [ˈsnʌb]
Examples: 'I felt snubbed when I waited for hours and nobody showed up'; 'He thought his ex-girlfriend had forgotten about him, but it was just a simple case of being misunderstood.',"Part of Speech: verb, noun
Definition: 'Snub' as a verb means to ignore or treat with contempt
column2: 'snub' as a noun refers to an act of ignoring someone.

column1:
daemon [ˈdɛ.mən]
Examples: 'The computer Daemon processes background tasks at all times.'; 'She decided to daemonize her project so it would run continuously in the server without user interaction.',"Part of Speech: noun, verb (informal)
Definition: 'A helpful or benevolent spirit that guides and protects individuals.' Noun
column2: 'to usefully employ the efforts of an unseen force for one's own purposes.' Verb

column1:
wedlock /wɛdˈlɔk/
Examples: They celebrated their wedlock with family at the church; His parents were overjoyed to witness his new-found happiness after years apart due to work.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: the legal union of a man and woman in marriage.

bourgeoisie /ˈbuːrɡɔɪzi/
Examples: The bourgeoisie invested heavily in local businesses; The concept of 'bourgeois' was central to Marx's critique of capitalism,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A social class characterized by a focus on cultural and economic interests, typically the middle or affluent members of society within capitalist societies.
Synonyms: 'middle class,' 'affluent group,' 'property owners,' 'capitalists (in a broader sense)', 'upper-class citizens'
Antonyms: 'proletariat, working class,' 'underprivileged groups,' 'lower class,' 'destitute people'"

notary [ˈnɑːtəri]
Examples: I had my signature witnessed by a notary; The couple went before the county notary for their wedding license.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A public official authorized to administer an oath or affirmation of statutory declarations, such as marriage, separation and immigration documents.

ethnicities /ˈɛθɪˌnæʃ.i.əties/
Examples: In a country with multiple ethnicities, the celebration of diverse holidays is common; Ethnocentrism often arises from ignorance about other ethnicities in one's vicinity.,"Part of Speech: plural noun
Definition: The cultural, religious, or national groups that share similar heritage and social customs.

elitist /ɪˈlɪt.ɪst/
Examples: The university administration is often accused of being too much of an elitist institution because it favors students from wealthy backgrounds over those struggling academically.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: a person who believes in and advocates the rule of only a select, privileged group
column2: someone with elitist attitudes or views.

column1:
contemporary /ˈkɒn.tɪˌmənt.pər.taɪm/;
Examples: The contemporary artist exhibited at the Louvre; The building was designed with a modern, contemporary look.,"Part of Speech: adjective and noun
Definition: Contemporary: belonging to or occurring in the same time period (adjective)
column2: relating to modern art, music, dancers etc., from about 1940 onwards.

column1:
institutions /ˈˌɪnst̪əkʃn̩tz/
Examples: Educational institutions like schools and universities; healthcare institutions such as hospitals and clinics,"Part of Speech: plural noun
Definition: Structures or organizations founded and maintained for a purpose within society, often with legal status.

lucrative /luːˈkrɪ.tɪv/
Examples: 'The pharmaceutical industry offers many lucrative positions for qualified researchers.'; 'She sold her vintage car and used the cash to start a more lucrative career.',"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: having a profitable result or financial advantage
column2: providing material benefit, especially in the form of money.

column1:
patriarchal ˈpætəˌrɪkəl
Examples: Many Western cultures are historically patrilineal and therefore patriarchal; the term 'patriarchy' is often used in gender studies to describe these systems.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: characterized by a social system in which men hold primary power and predominate in roles of political leadership, moral authority, social privilege and control of property
column2: also relating to patriarchy or referring to societies based on this.

column1:
fostering ˈfɒstərɪŋ
Examples: 'My cousin is a social worker; she specializes in adoption and often helps with the fostering process.' 'The couple had always wanted to open their home so decided they would start by fostering one child from another country.',"Part of Speech: verb, noun
Definition: nurturing a child or young person by assuming their parental responsibility
column2: the act of providing care and support to someone (especially in place of parents). 'The couple decided to foster three children from different backgrounds.'
column3: verb - To provide temporary family for an abandoned, neglected, homeless, or orphaned child.

column1:
eroded ˈɪərəʊd ˌiːtʃt; -ed…
Examples: 'The river had eroded the soft soil over many years.' 'His confidence was worn down after constant criticism,',"Part of Speech: verb, adjective
Definition: to wear away gradually by natural agents such as water, ice, and wind.

palatable ˈpælətəbəl;
Examples: The soup had a rich and palatable broth. Despite trying the new sushi place, my brother found nothing palatable; She prefers her chocolate with almonds over plain ones for their more complex flavor profile that is generally considered to be less bitter and thus more palatable.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: pleasant to taste or acceptable in flavor, agreeable.

apparent /ˈæpərənt/
Examples: An apparent advantage to the deal may not actually benefit both parties in the long run. It was obvious from her expression and tone of voice that she had an 'apparent' smile on her face, which wasn't quite genuine.,"Part of Speech: adjective, noun (less common)

innate /ˌɪnˈeɪt/
Examples: The artist had an innate sense of color theory from a young age.; The baby's laughter seemed more genuine because it was so deeply rooted in its nature;,"Part of Speech: adjective

column2: innate quality, especially of intelligence or ability. Refers to something that is natural and inherent rather than acquired through experience.

column1: Synonyms: inborn, instinctive, natural, inherent, native, original.
Antonyms: acquired skill, learned trait, artificial."

groomed /ˈɡruːmd/
Examples: The horse was groomed before the race; She always likes to have her desk area groomed every morning,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: trimmed, primed and neat for appearance or use
column2: cared about in terms of style (of a person)

column1:
equate /ɪˈkweɪt/
Examples: Many people equate love with marriage, but this is a common misconception.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: to consider synonymous or equivalent

barnacles /ˈbɑr.nək.li/
Examples: The barnacles clung stubbornly to the hull of the ship.; Farmers often despise having barnacle-encrusted tools on their farm equipment.,"Part of Speech: adjective and noun
Definition: An adjective meaning 'fixed or attached in a tight, difficult way
column3: A noun referring to small crustaceans with hard shells that attach themselves permanently to solid surfaces.

column1:
drudgery [ˈdrʌdʒəri]
Examples: 'I've been doing this boring drudgery job for years with no hope of promotion.' 'She tackled her homework with the same level of enthusiasm as she would any other mundane chore – total dedication to drudgery.,"Part of Speech: noun

column2: a monotonous and tiresome task or duty, often requiring little skill.

column1:
uncanny /ʌnsˈkɛni/
Examples: Her uncanny ability to predict stock market trends was both impressive and slightly frightening.; The abandoned house had an uncanny resemblance to our childhood home, evoking memories I thought were long forgotten.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: having or appearing to possess qualities that are mysterious and beyond the understanding of natural laws
column2: eerie in a way that causes fear or discomfort.

column1:
grain /ɡreɪn/
Examples: The wheat is ready for harvesting after the last rain has passed. She decided not to use her hands and instead used machinery with large grains as sieves to separate kernels from chaff.,"Part of Speech: noun, verb
Definition: A small grain of a cereal
column2: to sow seeds by dropping them in rows.

column1:
subtlest /ˈsuːtli.əst/
Examples: 'The most subtlest of all her jokes fell flat.' 'He could feel the chill as he whispered his secret to me—it was so subtilly felt that it seemed physical.',"Part of Speech: adjective

column2: very delicate, slight or faint in a negative sense.

column1:
primate /ˈprɪm.ə.tiz/
Examples: Humans are primates; lemurs also belong to this diverse group.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A primate is a member of the mammalian order Primates, which includes humans, apes, monkeys, and prosimians.

subtler ˌsʌblˈtriːə, -treɪl-
Examples: The artist's work is not as subtle and nuanced as the original masterpiece. Her arguments were much more persuasive, making her points seem almost subterranean compared to his blunt remarks.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: more delicate or refined in manner
